subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12th November (vide page 3117), on motion, by Mr. W. H. Irvine -

quote.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: .- The unfortunate wickedness of the Melbourne Age has interrupted my remarks upon this Bill. I do not propose to repeat my opening words that I gave last night, nor do I intend to deal with more than a few points upon which I feel called on to make some reply to the Attorney-General. I was pleased to hear the Attorney-General admit the value and importance of the trade union movement, and to hear him say that workmen ought to join unions, thus showing no sympathy with those who hold aloof from unions. ' His reference to guilds reminded a- few of us of the occasion when we were entertained in London by the representatives of some of the ancient guilds, notably the Drapers and Mercers. In one case we were shown a charter 800 years old. Some of the guilds cannot tell when they began. I mention these things to indicate the big part guilds have played in the building up of the various nations, and the changes that they have made in their methods of working to suit the conditions of life in which they are now living. One guild has an annual income of £96,000. Originally they purchased 2½ acres of land in the heart of London for evening walks for drapers' apprentices, at a cost of £2,500, and that block, of course, has become so enormously valuable that they get 30s., in the shape of ground rent, for every superficial foot. They spend the money in education and in charity. The history of the guilds is an interesting one, showing how dependent civilization, advance, and progress, are on cooperation - which is one term for it - or associating together. This is not confined to industrial matters. I am an earnest believer in, and advocate of, organization and union in every section of the community. Every section has its own interests in relation to other people, and every individual in a section should join in union with his fellows. I have advocated the formation of a farmers' union. The farmers have their association. I have ho objection to the Medical Association. Though they are a, strong organization, probably the strongest, with the exception of the lawyers, their management is to be admired. Association is the real bedrock of civilization. We have first the family, and' then the tribe, and the way in which the tribe operates builds up the nation. Looking back, we learn how much' we owe to the combination and association of individuals. It is strange to see the number of persons and political parties there are, even at the present day, who would like to stamp out trade unionism. Some look on it as a good thing, but when it touches them they try to crush it out. I propose to "describe some of the points in connexion with the working of our unions that are, perhaps, not known to honorable members on the other side. The man in the street seems to have the impression that a trade union is a body which is liable 'at any time to make unreasonable demands upon the employers, and whose whole attention is engrossed by the question .of hours and wages. I propose to-night to answer the Attorney-General's query as to what unions do for the public good to deserve the consideration for which they are asking. That is a fair question to put. I propose to give it an answer quite different from that which was interjected across the table last night. M. F. Robinson Bays -

quote.para: In Great Britain we find that the spirit qf association is interwoven with the entire fabric . of our religious, social, industrial, commercial, and political life. It touches vital issues at all points. It vests itself in ever-changing guise throughout the centuries, but the principle qf mutual aid, which is its underlying motive, is as natural to man as is the migratory instinct to the birds, which are drawn in flocks across the seas in spring and autumn. _ Our whole national history is impregnated with voluntary associative effort.

speech.para: We should not forget that associated efforts for the common good destroys the narrow individual selfishness of men, making them think more of the interests of their fellows. When men fall into various groups in society, every trade becomes an organization.

talk.start.para: - Voluntary.

- There is no other thing possible than voluntary association, but what does " voluntary " mean ? There are limits to every person's individual freedom. .From the guild days up to the present trade union era, it has- always been true., that all associations are law makers. By himself, the individual is practically powerless. He becomes effective only when he gets a group associated with him. Every organization, whether a church, an employers' federation, .or a trade union, has courts within its own jurisdiction, and this was so even as far back as the days of Edward I., as shown by the following quotation from W. J. Ashley's Economic History -

quote.para: The guild system- was no longer merely tolerated; it was fostered and extended, though doubtless primarily, for police purposes - to ensure due supervision of the craft, and the punishment of offenders against -regulations, through persons chosen by ' the craft, but responsible to the municipal authorities.

speech.para: In some things- we are reviving old principles. Even in that early period, the -craft or guild was an influence for good, and even under our Federal Arbitration Act the modern trade unions are used to police the awards. Each union has its rules, and the effect of membership is to discipline men, broaden their interests, and make them law-abiding subjects. That is' one great reason why trade unions should be recognised and encouraged. The first step in this, direction in Australia was taken by the late Charles Cameron Kingston, and his example was afterwards followed in New Zealand, the Arbitration Act of which country states in its preamble that its object is to encourage and foster unions. In the days of Edward I., there was an immense number of guilds, and their spirit, which is the spirit of association, is perpetuated in the modern trade union movement. But to-day it goes further, and has wider effects. The first step towards forming an organization may be such a simple thing as a meeting to arrange a deputation to a Minister. That involves collective action, and good results follow. The disciplinary effect of the trade union movement is becoming more and more marked every day, and it is worth the while of a Legislature like this to look into the matter. This Bill is quite a harmless kind of thing, but it forms a text for a discussion that is well worth spending a little time over. There is a very false impression on the part of the Government and their following, and employers generally, as to the meaning of the term " non-unionist." That this is so in the case of the present Government is shown by the terminology of. this Bill, for they seem to assume that because a man is not a member of a union he is a non-unionist. That is the greatest mistake they can make. The men against whom I 'have had strong things to say, and against whom I shall again say strong things, are men about whom there is nothing too strong- to be said. They are' traitors.. Every people denounces those who, when their nation is fighting for its life against an oppressor, sell its secrets. To do a thing of that kind is to commit -what is considered one of the most serious crimes, and those who do such things are generally held worthy of death. Those to whom we apply strong epithets- are the anti-unionists, who, for pay, and, in some cases, because of slavish instincts, turn against their fellow men. But only a small number of such men, comparatively speaking, now exist, and the number is lessened every day. They are not numerous enough for it to be worth the while of any Government to bother about, and certainly do not deserve consideration. The Attorney-General commenced by extolling, as every intelligent man must, the importance and value of trade unionism ; but, when he went on to say that there are persons who need protection from it, he showed that he has not got into close grips with the facts of life. There are men who are not members of unions, but who are unionists in spirit.

talk.start.para: - Do you make a distinction between anti-unionists and non-unionists 1

- There are over some 400,000 members o'funions, and it is sometimes attempted to prove that "those who are outside unions are anti-unionists; but that is a mistake, because there are hosts of industries which it has not been found necessary to organize.
- Then you have no objection to "the men who stand 'Out of unions, provided they are -riot anti- unionists ?

speech.para: Mr.SPENCE. - I shall come to that. The anti-unionists, whom we 'denounce so strongly, are the men who 'refuse to join the unions, 'and Who stand -by the employers in times of trouble - the strike- breakers. I have said that there are not so many of them now. There "are other men who make mistakes, 'and 'at; first decline 'to join, but come round 'later. There is no feeling against them . But there is in 'Melbdurne -today an organized strike- breakers' 'union, subsidized a'nd paid Tjy the 'EmployersFederation,tofight against genuine unionists. No 'Government having a 'grip -of 'the conditions would do anything to help a -class like 'that.

talk.start.para: -Apartfrom 'the strike-breakers, "you nave, I understand, no objection to the fine 'men "who voluntarily remain 'outsideunions?

- Honorable members will not use the term "anti-unionists,'' and 'the Attorney-General has declared that men ought to . join unions. There is no monopoly in unionism, and 'no ' claim to the monopoly of work is made by unionists. No such claim was ever made. "We ask for . prefterence 'to unionists as against anti-unionists, and "I 'shall show how that work's in practice. Some of the unions 'had objectionable "rules, providing for prohibitive en trance fees; but, since the settlement bf 'industrial disputes by legal tribunals 'has ''beenestablished,such entrance f ees have been abolished. "When the 'principleof "pref erence . to unionists is recognised, consideration is "first "given to the question of efficiency ; and, finally, all other things being equal> if bf the two applicants for a job one is a unionist and the other is not, the unionist gets it. But, in practice, a man who wants a job joins a union, if he knows that he cannot get it without doing so.
- In the exercise bf his liberty, a man may decline to join a union.

- The men do not refuse to join unions. The honorable gentleman, like many others, imagines difficulties which do not exist, except 'so far as the anti -unionists are concerned, who are paid to take a stand. There is no coercion needed, and none is applied. There have been cases in which coercion has been Used, and I shall deal with them presently. But let us consider what happened under "therégime of the last 'Government. Honorable members opposite make a great deal of fuss -about what was done 'by that Administration ; 'bu"t they have not heard the complaints that I have heard against that Government for not 'giving preference to unionists. The good, old, staunch unionists did -not 'always get 'the ' job. When a strike was organized at Port Darwin, who organized it? The Attorney -General wishes to make out that the last Government gave preference to men o'f its own particular views ; but the complaint of trade unionists was that Liberals, and not- Labourites, got the jobs. The Northern Territory dispute was 'engineered by the opposite side in politics, "and the men who got the . jobs in the Northern Territory were ""ticket" unionists. In 'the Sydney . newspapers, it was stated that the strikers were Australian Workers Union men, 'but "the genera1! secretary -of the Australian 'Worker's -Union denied -that. A number of 'the men . joined the cheapest union they . could find, got a ticket, and then went 'for a job. Those men can'n'dt be called Unionists -in : principle, and there . was preference . to . unionists in their case only in a technical sense. When men 'find it : to their advantage, they do not let the want of a unionist ticket prevent them from getting a job. ThisGovernment is putting up a fight on behalf of individuals who do hot want to join unions. It imagines that the unions are tyrannical, 'and we are asked 'why should "men 'pay contributions 'to "unions ? "Men do not pay contributions 'to unions.

speech.para: Mr.BruceSmith.- They are persuaded to do so with the aid of a brick.

talk.start.para: - I am not now dealing with coercion, though I may remark, parenthetically, that coercion may be a good thing. No doubt the honorable member is much better than he would otherwise have been because of the canings that he got when a boy. It is a myth that men object to join unions. But there is nothing wrong in demanding that the members of unions shall contribute to the support of the organizations that have obtained privileges for them. No one will say that that is unreasonable. I could give figures which prove that live, militant trade unionism has greatly increased, wages, and has improved the position of the workers to such an extent that they have gained much more than they have paid in fees. That is to say, the industry really pays their fees. When a man in such an industry refuses to join a union, on the plea that he cannot afford to pay its fees, he is stating what is not true. He wishes to enjoy the gains that have been won by the union without paying for them, and if others followed his example there would soon be no organization to protect what has been won. Moreover, under our arbitration law, unionism is necessary for the presentation to the Court of industrial disputes. In civic and in national life, the individual is not allowed to escape his share of taxation, and it is not reasonable that those who enjoy the' benefits of unionism should not contribute towards the maintenance of those benefits. There is an old saying that when there is a shrew in the neighbourhood, every one hears of her, while not a word is said of the thousands of good women there. The good things that are done in this world are largely hidden. We hear occasionally of some case of coercion. I do not claim that everything done by every group of men is right. Groups of men make mistakes just as individuals do, a group being virtually a big giant, and liable to make mistakes just as the individuals who compose it are so liable. But the incidents of which so much is made occur very rarely. Moreover, as I have said, coercion is not an evil thing. Our . laws are coercive.
- Coercion by a lawmaking authority is absolutely necessary.

- Organization assists in moulding public opinion, and in forming customs, and this is ultimately recognised in the Statute law. When Parliament passes an Act, it imposes obligations upon a small minority of the community which will not do voluntarily what the majority has done voluntarily without that Act. That is what Adam Smith meant when he said that laws beyond the aggregate intelligence of a community are not observed. Some of the laws on our statute- books to-day are not observed because they have gone out of . use. I suggest to my honorable friends opposite that there may be some good in a certain amount of coercion. When I was over in Tasmania beginning the organization of the Australian Workers "Union in that State - and perhaps the honorable member for Wilmot will have some recollection of the matter - an effort was made to make something out of my remark that the Australian Workers Union representatives were coming over to Tasmania as missionaries for the purpose of civilizing a number of the employers in that State. We were missionaries for their good. The honorable member for Riverina knows what was the position of shearers in the old days. They came long distances to hear the wool for men who would not speak to them. The pastoralist might throw a grunt over his shoulder to them, but he would not speak to them. We civilized him.
- The honorable member is not personal, I hope.

- No; I am not saying a word about the honorable member, but he knows very well that there were many very unreasonable employers, who had no consideration for the men who did their work. I say that the unions civilized those employers, and made them treat their "employes as human beings ought to be treated. They, made them think of something outside their own little narrow kingdom. I say that the unions made those men better men, and caused them to take an interest in things in which they took no interest before. I had a long experience with one group of men, and studied these matters in detail. The father of the honorable member for Wimmera was one of my colleagues at the time, and the first president of the union to which I am now referring. He suffered in the cause, was boycotted, and prevented from obtaining work. He was hunted, and he knew what a fight had to be put up. During a period of about sixteen years, I remember only three cases where coercive action had to be used to make men join the Amalgamated Miners Association. That was at the beginning of things, and when unionism was not so popular as it is now.
- There was coercion among the shearers.

- There has been; but in every case of the kind the man coerced has been made a better man. Previous to the coercion, he was utterly selfish and cared only for what he could gain from the efforts of his fellow workers. I do not advocate coercion, and I say that cases of the kind are always exaggerated, that there are very few of them, and that there is another side to the coercion which is not generally considered. I have referred to the use of the cane in schools, where the necessity for personal chastisement is recognised. I can give an illustration of . an extreme case of this kind that occurred in the Parramatta Gaol. There were 750 prisoners in the gaol, and their lives were made more hard than they would otherwise have been by the action of a bully, until the advent of a shearer known as " Smiler," a splendid fellow, who, because he was a unionist, was sent to the gaol. The bully tried the same game on with him, and attempted to tyrannize over him as he had done over the other prisoners, but this man " took to him," and gave him a hiding. I was present when this prisoner, who settled the bully, received the thanks of the governor of the gaol for doing what he and the warders could not do. The shearer gave the bully a hiding with his bare knuckles, and after it the bully was anybody's dog, to kick anywhere. I am suggesting that there is sometimes good in coercion, and honorable members will admit that a parent will use the cane occasionally upon his children.
- But the honorable member would not allow the bully next door to use it on his children.
- There is no question of a bully next door, or of any bully.
- Is there not?

- I say that if our friends opposite knew all the particulars in some of the cases of coercion which have been made so much of, they would admit that, in the circumstances, they would have used the coercion themselves. I deny that there are any number of such cases, and I come back to my statement that an association of any kind,, to be good, must be voluntary, and society does not allow individuals to set at defiance the law approved by the people as a whole.
- The honorable member means that association ought to be voluntary, with a little coercion thrown in sometimes, when necessary?

- I want it to be understood that I am not contending that no mistakes have been made, or that harsh things have not been done; but I say that there is no necessity whatever to protect anybody who does not want to be a member of a union. I say that the number of anti-unionists is extremely limited. They are all " bad eggs," and if I were an employer, I would not have them about the place. When they fail to be true to their fellow-men, they may be expected to take advantage of their employers whenever they get the chance. I have always argued that employers should not question whether a man who comes to them for employment is a unionist or a non-unionist. The bigger unions are not now very much concerned about preference. They get it in virtue of their power. It is true that the Australian Workers Union applied to the Court for preference and were, refused it, but we were not very much concerned about it. Practically all engaged in the industry are members of the union, and remain members, and there is no difficulty about it when men consider the immense- gain they receive for the very small sum they are required to pay in contributions. I admit that, in the earlier days, there were some fairly rough things done. I have quoted one case before, where one of our organizers believed in immersion, and said that he never found anybody who required more than three dips to make him a convert. Where you have about 50,000 men to deal with, and there is only one case of coercion in a year, that is not much to make a noise about.
- That is approval of coercion.

- It is not a question of approval. My honorable friend is not responsible for things being done which he does not approve of. Who makes a song about one- case ? What we, as legislators, have to consider is the general effect.
- The coroner sometimes makes a song about it.

- The Australian Workers Union is on good terms with employers, and has been working under an award for some years past. Members of the Australian Workers Union do their best to make pastoralists join the Pastoralists Union. We believe in unionism for our employers. The reason is that things can be worked more harmoniously when two collective bodies make mutual agreements. The press publish any story they may hear of coercion by the unions, whether it be with or without foundation, but if they published what I know to be the truth regarding the action of the Pastoralists Union and their coercive efforts to bring men into their organization, they would find that it has been quite as bad, if not worse, than any coercion by the Australian Workers Union. In some trades, such as that to which the honorable member for Dalley belongs, every man in the industry is in the union, because such -unions will not admit any but trained tradesmen. But the general unions admit anybody, and their doors are open to intending members all the time. I propose briefly to refer to political action by unions. The Government believe that men should not be made to contribute to unions which devote their funds to political purposes.
- No; not that they should not be compelled to join a union that takes political action, but that if they are members of a political union, they should not claim preference from the Government.
- The Government have objected to trade unions having political matters amongst their objects.
- No; to their having political preference.

- They would put a bar in the way of such unions if they could. That is extremely foolish, because these unions will get preference- in spite of it. The alleged justification for the attitude of the Government 'is that somebody is being coerced to contribute to something he does not believe in. There is a large number of unions, and very big unions, such as the Newcastle Miners Union, that do not contribute anything from union funds to political organization. The Australian Workers Union is political, and we are proud of it, but they never put money in their funds for political purposes unless, as is provided for by their rules, a plebiscite is taken on the proposal, and it is carried by a two-thirds majority. So that some degree of unanimity is provided for before any portion of the contribution of the members of the union is used for political purposes. The Attorney-General has said that large sums are allocated for political purposes, but let me tell him that, during a period of twenty-five years, it is only a matter of a few years since money was used directly from the funds of unions for political purposes. The union organizers are really out for industrial organization, but I quite admit that incidentally they do a certain amount of political organization, because they see that men have their names put on the rolls. We have sent out political organizers, who are paid as such under the considerations I speak of. That is shown in the ordinary balance-sheets of the Australian Workers Union, and I can speak as to their correctness. The Attorney-General made a somewhat extraordinary statement when he quoted the payments towards The Worker newspaper, and said they should be included because the newspaper carries on a political propaganda. On that argument, for instance, I am paying 6d. a week to help along the Melbourne Argus, and, as it is a Liberal newspaper, I am paying far more to help along a Liberal organization than I am paying into the union. That is not sound logic. A man gets value for the newspaper, and the union could not work without a weekly organ.
- The shearers have to take the newspaper.

- Every man gets more than full value for his contribution of 5s., as anybody will admit. The union could not be worked, and the unionist could not know what was doing, or what he was expected to do, without the newspaper. He is getting full value for his money, altogether apart from its effect on politics. The older unions all dealt with political questions. Take any congress which has ever met. What did it deal with? Take the Amalgamated Miners Association in Victoria, which for some years did not touch politics. Out of fifty-four questions there were only four with which the union could deal in their many conferences, every one of which cost £400. ' What sense is there in unions meeting together at considerable expense, passing resolutions that demand political action, and doing nothing more than that? Would any body of sensible men not follow up their deliberations by using their funds to carry out the ideas on which they were, unanimous?
- Nobody suggested that they should not.
- That is forgotten. The Attorney-General and others spoke of this political movement as something which is wrong.
- No, I never suggested that.

- Then I cannot understand the honorable member's attitude. There is no coercive influence used at all, and there is no objection raised in the place where it can be heard. The men do not raise any objection to paying the contribution into a union which spends a certain amount of political funds, consequently no one is injured. The object in taking up political aims is to lessen the risk and the need for strikes. Industrial peace and political action go together. One is promotive of the other. That is the basic principle of all associated effort. The proper thing is to carry a matter to Parliament. That has been done in England, and here we are trying by constitutional and peaceful methods to carry into effect certain reforms, instead of having to fight for them industrially. I am sorry that owing to the lack of time I cannot cover the great field which I should like to traverse to-night. In his speech, the Attorney-General quoted from the Sydney Worker, and, I am sorry to say, misled the House.
- In what respect?
- The honorable member quoted this paragraph -

quote.para: Don't be surprised if 1913 presents us with some of the greatest strikes on record.

speech.para: The honorable member made that quotation, and apparently caused the House to think that it was the editorial opinion of the Sydney Worker.

talk.start.para: - I said exactly what it was. I said that it was in a column headed " Coming Strikes."

- I say no. The honorable member led the House to infer that the paragraph referred to Australia. It is not the official opinion of the Sydney Worker, nor does it apply to Australia. The evidence is given at the top, if the honorable gentleman had read it -

quote.para: The Outlook, A Survey of World Progress. Conducted by H. E. Boote.

speech.para: The writer is a very able, brilliant journalist, who contributes sometimes two or three, columns, and sometimes a page. He starts off with the 9th January, and asks, " What has the new year got in store for us?" and lower down, under the heading of " Coming Strikes," he deals, not with Australia at all1, but a case in New York. The Attorney-General could not have read the contribution, because the context shows clearly, what the writer is referring to. He contributes an interesting review based on the world's outlook, not on the Australian outlook.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member will do me the justice to admit that I read that for the purpose of showing that the political attitude of The Worker was not averse to strikes.
- The honorable member admits that he misled the House.
- I do not admit anything of the kind.

- If the honorable member will excuse me, he does. The writer does not express the view of The Worker, nor does he express approval of strikes or otherwise. If the honorable member had read the preceding part, he would have seen that the writer is giving a forecast " from the watch tower." Taking the outlook for the world, he says there may be some serious strikes in 1913. He is assuming the rôle of a prophet, but he does not refer to Australia. It is a very interesting contribution. Lower down the writer mentions that trouble has already begun. In the next paragraph he says-

quote.para: It is not difficult to foresee that in every country where capitalism tyrannises there will be revolts against the tyranny.

speech.para: So he continues. The Attorney- General could not have looked at the top of the article, or he would not. have quoted the paragraph he did.

talk.start.para: - Order ! The honorable member's time has expired .

speech.para: Mr.FALKINER (Riverina) [9.35].- The honorable member for Darling is so pleasant and persuasive that I can only express my feeling in the first words of a line of the hymn, " Almost persuaded." He said that unionism had civilized the employer, and I think in some cases it was necessary. In those cases my honorable friend was right, but I regret to say unionism, as we know it in the bush in Australia, has not civilized the unionists, because it has created such a class feeling, such a spirit of hostility, that very often a man who works for an employer, or who wants work, will hardly look at him as he passes him going along the road. That, I think, is deplorable. It is one of the effects of unionism in the bush in Australia. As regards unionism being a discipline for men's character, for making them obey law and order, it certainly does, so long as it is the law and order of the head of the union, but not otherwise. For myself, I do not object to unionism at all, and as a member of the Pastoralists Union, I may say that we are very pleased to have our friends' assistance in getting pastoralists to join, so that we can bargain collectively, and make better agreements. Unfortunately, we cannot adopt the methods of our friends. Another statement which the honorable member made was that the unions spend very little money on industrial political organization. Every organizer for the Australian Workers Union is a political organizer, if he is anything. A man has to have his ticket and do what they tell him.

talk.start.para: - Do you object to that?

- I will come to that later. Several statements have been made regarding unionism to which I take exception. One statement is that unionism means efficiency. It does nothing of the sort. It only means that a man has a ticket from a certain union. I am sure that it" does not mean efficiency, because I have employed union cooks, and have been forced to sack them by union men.
- You look well on your feed.

- I did not have to eat what the man cooked, but I no sooner went out on the platform than I was twitted with the fact that my men did not look well. Of course, I had to make the obvious retort that the rations were liberal, but the cook was labour. There is no qualification for a unionist. He serves no time. All that he has to do is to take out a union ticket. The unionist has been likened to a professional man. The latter had to serve some years in learning the art or science which he practices, and if he is no good, he gets paid accordingly. That is not so with the unionist. He claims the full rate of wage whether he is efficient or not. We are not fighting unionism. Much has been said about the matter.
- Do you not sack a shearer if he does not do his work properly ?

- No. I do not sack him, because there is an etiquette in the profession that, if you sack a man, nobody will take his place. I make the man do his work under pain of suing him for a breach of contract, with the result that no one will come to me, and I have had to employ the contract shearer, who is an abomination in the sight of the honorable member for Darling. When I was on the platform endeavouring to get a seat here - and that was not an easy job, I may say - nothing created more interest, or secured me more votes, than did my reference to the large increase in the number of Government employes, not only in the Public Service, but on all the works done by day labour, and in the different factories started by the late Government. I pointed out that it was creating a class who were dependent upon the State for their support.
- Do we not all depend on the State?
- No ; I depend upon my own effort.
- You do nothing of the kind.
- Order !
- The State is everything.

- Order 1 The honorable member for Brisbane appears to be deliberately refusing to acknowledge the call of the Chair to order. I trust it will not again be necessary for me to remind him of his duty to the House.

- The whole result of this policy will be to create a huge political machine. That is the goal of the Labour party, and the producer will simply be a working bullock for the Public Service. Our honorable friends would make employment depend upon political support, and, in their turn, they would not give a job to a man unless he would give them political support. In Parliament we hear a lot of pleasant things. In reply to a question which I put to him last night, the Leader of the Opposition stated that a unionist is at liberty to vote as he thinks fit. I give that statement a flat contradiction.
- Hundreds of miners in my district vote against the Labour candidate.
- I am not talking about the honorable member's district, but about my own.

speech.para: Mr.Riley. - Does the honorable member say that there are no shearers who vote for him ?

talk.start.para: - I will deal with that point directly. A unionist should be at liberty to vote as he chooses, because, if his leaders should be going too far, it is the only check which he can impose upon them. But in the contest for the representation of Riverina, the Unionists were not permitted to vote as they pleased. I have lived a long time in my electorate, and I have had as close an acquaintance with working men as has any honorable member of this House. During the recent election campaign, some members of the Carriers Union decided to support me. I will tell honorable members what happened, and I say that it happened through the agency of the Australian Workers Union. Now, I think the majority of Labour members in this Parliament who represent country constituencies owe their positions to the Australian Workers Union. " Every organizer connected with that union is either in Parliament or has contested a seat for Parliament, with the exception of the coloured gentleman who organizes in my own' district.
- He is a good fellow.
- I know that, and be is more intelligent than are a lot of white persons. It is a very sore point with my honorable friends that they have to employ a black man to organize for them.
- The honorable member discovered his intelligence when he pitted himself against him, I suppose ?

- I would not like to say who is the better man. At any rate, this coloured organizer is much more gentle in his methods than are my honorable friends opposite. There is a Carriers Union at Tocumwal, and, in order to show the difference which exists between the theory of the honorable member for Wide Bay and actual practice, I propose to read a report from the local newspaper. That report is as follows -

quote.para: A special meeting of the TocumwalCarriers' Union was held at the Mechanics' Institute on Saturday evening for the purpose of dealing with those members of the union who had signed the requisition to Mr. F. B. S. Falkiner to contest the Riverina electorate against Mr. Chanter.

speech.para: After dealing with another matter, and accusing me of having said one or two things which I did not say, the report proceeds -

quote.para: He regretted that he had been sent along in connexion with the matter of a requisition to Mr. Falkiner, signed by a number of members of the Carriers' Union.

talk.start.para: - Who said this?
- Mr. Evans, the organizer of the Australian Carriers Union -

quote.para: He thought it was a trivial affair at first, but found now that it was getting serious, and must be adjusted.

speech.para: Further on it says-

quote.para: Mr. Falkiner was a good man, but no carrier who was a member of the union could support him, because later on they would have to fight Mr. Falkiner in the Arbitration Court. Those who had signed the requisition would have to stick to the union or get out and support Mr. Falkiner.

speech.para: I may say that these carriers were told to get out of the union. Five of them did get out, but the other seven refused to do so. I believe that all of them voted for me except one fellow, who was afraid of his wife. The organizer, in concluding the business, said -

quote.para: He felt sorry for the attitude of a number of the carriers here. As soon as he got back to Hay he would endeavour to move for their expulsion from the union.

speech.para: I do not think they were expelled. They did not go to the Carriers Union for their tickets - they got them from the Australian Workers Union. This Bill does not seek to prevent unions from using their funds for political purposes. It merely aims at preventing them from obtaining a preference. Its object is to stop the Civil Service of this country from being made a huge political machine for the benefit of the Labour party. The honorable member for West Sydney stated that the measure will affect only 12,000 Government employes. But the principle is a good one if it affects only one employe. If honorable members opposite could control the votes of only 6,000 Government employes, that would have been sufficient to enable them to win six or seven seats at the last election.

talk.start.para: - It all depends on where the seats were
- And upon the candidates.
- Is that the number of votes which the honorable member estimates his party will gain as the result of the passing of this Bill?

- I wish, sir, the honorable member would keep that little soprano voice quiet. The Opposition remind me of grand opera; their voices range from the deep bass of the honorable member for Maranoa to the light mezzo-soprano of the honorable member for Batman. The desire to give preference to unionists is one of the objections which can be urged against day labour. The honorable member for West Sydney said that, whether a man works for the Government or for a contractor, he will still be employed under the day-labour system. He declared that the real question was that of supervision. That is so. We wish to prevent a condition arising under which those charged with the supervision of day labour on Government works will be dependent upon the men under them for their political existence.' The honorable member for Darling stated . that unionists have assisted the Pastoralists Union to get members into that organization. I admit that. But the members of our organization recognise that we have no right to force a man into it against his conscientious convictions. There is no more reason why a man should be a unionist than there is that he should be a Unitarian. I feel that I shall be acting in the best interests of Australia by voting for the Bill.

.- In my opinion, the best that can be said of this measure is that it is unnecessary, whilst the worst that can be said of it is that it is an attempt on the part of the Government to create a situation out of which friction and ill-feeling will arise, from which they hope to benefit. I am not prepared to say what is their motive ; but, whatever it may be, the Bill is unnecessary, and constitutes an attempt to stir up strife which is undesirable. It is unnecessary, because, on the Attorney-General's own confession, what it purports to do has already been done.
- But it may be reversed by another Government.

- I recognise that another Government may effect such a change in administration as the present Government have already effected. Another Government may introduce a Bill for the repeal of this measure. Very little more trouble would be involved in doing that than would be involved in taking the administrative action which has been taken.
- Does not the honorable member think that the passing of a Bill will prevent a recurrence of the granting of preference?
- I ask the honorable member whether he thinks we can prevent the Government from doing anything they wish ?
- Honorable members opposite have prevented a few Bills from passing this session.

- The Prime Minister is not fair to me. My point is that this Bill is entirely unnecessary. It cannot effect any permanent change, for the reason, that a succeeding Government may entirely upset what has been done by its predecessors.
- That remark is applicable to all laws.

- I am aware of that. It is no more trouble to repeal an Act than it is to alter an administrative minute. There is nothing in the contention that my objection applies to all laws that we may enact, because there are some matters which can be dealt with only by an Act of Parliament. But here is a case in which it is unnecessary to adopt that course, because what honorable members opposite desire has already been accomplished hy a Ministerial minute.
- We want to provide that, if by any mischance the Labour party come into power again, they cannot grant a preference to unionists without an Act of Parliament.

- I do not think there is any point in that remark. Where is the difficulty in repealing an Act? This measure may be repealed by a succeeding Government, or if there is no Act, the object which they have in view may be attained by administrative minute. During the regime of the Fisher Government there was no absolute preference decreed. It was always a matter for the exercise of discretion. The very minute referred to laid it down that preference should be granted, " other things being equal," so that the present Government, merely by the exercise of its discretion, could have achieved what it wanted under that very minute, and without introducing this Bill. It could have declined to recognise that other things were equal in any case, and, if it had chosen to do so, could have determined that preference should be given to non-unionists. There was no occasion to introduce this Bill. In connexion with this measure the question of the official recognition of unions naturally crops up. Indeed, the whole question of unionism is involved. As the Attorney-General very ably pointed out last night, in these later days the institution of unionism is well established, well proved, and has come to stay. Honorable members must recognise the utility of unions, apart altogether from the benefits which they confer upon their members. Unionism does great service to the whole community by making it possible for the law to deal with composite bodies of men. Whether the .law deals effectively with them is . quite another matter. As a matter of fact, the law does not deal effectively with any subject. I do not know of any law that is so assiduously administered and so universally respected by the community that breaches of it never occur. Our industrial laws are comparatively new. Under them we have to deal with fresh situations and developments in society which are constantly arising, so that abuses are bound to occur. But as the result of the organization of labour, there is much less abuse than there would be if labour had chosen to run riot instead of combining and endeavouring to institute in its own name some system of law and order. The organizations of men in these unions is, to my mind, a splendid (evidence of their capacity to manage, at least to some extent, their own affairs, and to take an effective part in the conduct of the business of the country. These organizations to-day are a primary factor in all the activities of the social life of the Commonwealth, and that the workers should have organized themselves in this way is, to my mind, most commendable. By doing so, they have displayed the possession of that fine spirit of self-reliance and independence which is the outstanding feature of the British race. As has already been said, the thoroughly organized, well-established union does not want any legal preference. My constituency is not what might be termed a union electorate. I am not here as a purely union representative. I am, however, a strong advocate of unionism, and even those who are not in unions in my constituency support me because they believe in those aspects of unionism which appeal to me. They recognise that a union should be powerful enough to command its own preference by the benefits which it confers upon its members - that, just as friendly societies, by the benefits they offer, attract members, so a union naturally attracts craftsmen to its ranks, because of the undoubted benefits which it confers.
- Is that not the legitimate way?

- That is all very well, but if the Attorney-General believes in the passing of laws which will permit of unions reaching the Courts, and being dealt with as the Judiciary may consider wise, why should he object to union funds being applied to political purposes ? 'That aspect of unionism has really nothing to do with this matter.

- Does not every combination or association acquire strength by holding out advantages ? What would the honorable member say of a combination of farmers who said, " There must be a law to compel people to come into our organization ' ' ?

- I fail to see the application of the honorable member's argument. I do not think that the inducements held out by a union to men to join its ranks have anything to do with this Bill, and there is no question of compulsory unionism. Absolute preference is not, and has not, been demanded, nor has it been given. The late Ministry, in the exercise of its discretion, simply said, " Where possible, we shall give preference." In doing so, they were only coming into line with a law of the land which had been enacted because these bodies of men had had the good sense to combine, and make their presence felt. They had the good sense to combine and secure the return of men to this Parliament who were prepared to give them a voice in the Courts, and to see that the balance was held fairly between employers and employes. It was not held fairly before. Even honorable members opposite will not contend that the balance was held evenly until these men had access to the Courts. All that the law provides is that where a Judge deems it advisable to grant preference to unionists in order that the peace of the community may be preserved, he shall be at liberty to do so. That is an admirable solution nf a very delicate question, and one that ought to satisfy the present Government. They are not prepared, however, to accept the decision of the Judiciary in this matter. They say that this Bill is to override the Judiciary. A Judge may say, in the case of a dispute coming before him, " most of the persons in the trade to which this relates are members of a union, and I find that the trouble is being caused by a limited number who prefer to remain outside its ranks. These are causing friction, and may possibly precipitate a strike that may have disastrous . results. I decree, therefore, that there shall be preference to unionists in order that the peace of the community may be preserved." The Judiciary may also have to adjudicate between rival unions. But this measure will override any such decision. It may affect some body of men whom the Government desire to employ, and whose position as unionists may be used against them. If this Bill be passed, a unionist may not be employed in the circumstances. It is in this direction that the Bill may have very serious influences so far as its legal aspect is concerned'. On every ground, it seems to me to be utterly discredited. The law to-day takes cognisance of this very principle of preference to unionists. The difficulty has been solved in that way, and why should not the Government be prepared to leave to the Judiciary the question of whether or not preference shall be granted to unionists? Honorable members opposite have always urged the more rabid section of the community to abide by the decision of those who are specially qualified to see that justice is done, yet now they come forward with a purely party attempt-
- Against Ministerial preference.

- I am not objecting to that. If they object to Ministerial preference, let them give effect to their objection in the ordinary way instead of bringing forward a Bill which must give rise to a great deal of friction, and against which the Opposition are bound to protest. I believe in unionism, and those who share that belief with me cannot allow this Bill to pass unchallenged. I am sorry this situation has arisen. The Government, in introducing this Bill, seem to be looking for trouble. I can find no other explanation for their action. I have suggested what is a natural interpretation, but I am not prepared to say what are the real motives behind this action on their part. It certainly looks very suspicious from every point of view.
.- I do not intend to give a silent vote on this question.
- As a supporter of the Government the honorable member must justify it.

- I do not know whether it is necessary to justify my attitude, but in the past I have considered it my duty not to add to the volume of talk that has been going on. When I have discovered that the views I hold have been effectively voiced, I have refrained from taking part in a debate, believing that nothing is to be gained by reiterating sentiments that have already been uttered by honorable members on this side of the House. There are one or two aspects of this question, however, which have not yet been touched upon, and I propose very briefly to deal with them. In the first place, I fail to see that the introduction of this Bill offers any reasonable excuse for a lengthy dissertation on unionism per se. This Bill appears to me to be an admirable attempt to do away with what, in the opinion of the Government, and certainly in my judgment, is a very unfair and unreasonable system, under which a certain section of the community is given a preference over another section.
- It is an old Tory doctrine.

- Undoubtedly it is. We have been told by honorable members opposite that the only aristocrats of labour shall be those who happen to have had awarded to them the advantage of preference to unionists. I am much impressed with the admissions which have been made to-night by the honorable member for Darling. I was extremely pleased to hear the president of the Australian Workers Union candidly confess in this Chamber that that is a political organization.
- It has never been denied.
- And so are the Farmers and Settlers Associations.

- I know they are; and we have never hesitated to declare that fact to the public. But until to-night I had not had the statement from such an authority as the president of the Australian Workers Union that that is a distinctly political organization.
- The honorable member said that it was an industrial and political organization.

- I am expressing my satisfaction that this admission has been made, and I know that it is going to be very helpful. I was also pleased to hear the honorable member for Darling speak of his whole-hearted belief in voluntary unionism. I, too, am a whole-hearted believer in that principle, but what I object to is that class of unionism which requires to be prodded by what is commonly known as "moral suasion." I have before me an illustration of this, which I take from the Sydney Morning Herald of 17th February last - a paragraph in which it is recorded from Broken Hill that-

quote.para: The Horse-drivers' Wholesale Employes Union last night carried a resolution - " That this union notifies all unfinancial members and non-unionists connected with horse-driving and wholesale businesses, and all employes of such persons, that such employes must make themselves financial or become members by 28th February, or drastic action will be taken."

talk.start.para: - Does not the honorable member know that that is a purely industrial union, having no political aspect?

- Until to-night I was under the impression that the Australian Workers Union was a purely industrial union. There were certain reservations, but they have been broken down. I have no hesitation in saying that I have made efforts to ascertain definitely whether the Australian Workers Union claimed to be a political organization; but, unfortunately, until to-night, I had not been able to do so ; hence my great satisfaction at the frank statement of the honorable member for Darling.
- Why should action not be taken to recover arrears'?

- I do not object to that; but I do take exception to the " moral suasion " that we hear about. What I mean is such a suggestion as that a non-unionist, who is recalcitrant, can only stand ducking in the pond three times, or is not able to bear more than an 8-lb. brick, if it happens to fall upon him; or, again, that a shutter may fall down a shaft at the psychological moment on a non-unionist below. Such "moral suasion " as these occurrences represent is worthy only of execration. As a wholehearted believer in voluntary unionism, I am exceedingly pleased to hear that the honorable member for Darling shares my belief, although the honorable member knows, as well as I do, that, if there happen to be two or three non-unionists in a shed, who, in spite of all " moral suasion," refuse to pay their 15s., or whatever the fee may be, and to join the union on the spot, one of two things happens. These men have to pay the money--
- Or go on the road.
- Or go on the road.
- We "wood-heap" them now.
- I quite believe it; or the other men down their tools and themselves go on the road.
- They do not now; they have a better method.

- I have seen certain things, and I know what goes on. I am not surprised to find such wonderful unanimity on the Labour side of the House on the question of preference. In every claim trade unionists have made industrially, they have invariably inserted preference as a condition.
- That is an offset to victimization.
- The honorable member is speaking of the victimization of the unionist, but what about the victimization of the poor, unfortunate fellow who is not a member of the union?
- The honorable member never knows of the victimization of the unionists!

- No; and I do not wish to know. I simply desire to speak of things I know, and not of things I have heard at second hand. If honorable members would confine themselves to their actual knowledge, instead of indulging in a good deal of romancing, we might be saved many painful hours. The remarks of honorable members opposite would convey the impression that when a claim comes before the Arbitration Court or a Wages Board, it is between a master and a union.
- An employer and a union; there are no "masters" here.

- As a matter of fact,, it is simply a dispute between an employer and a number of employes, and not between an employer, or number of employers, and a union, unless it happens that the particular union is registered as an organization under the Federal Arbitration Act.
- An appeal cannot be made to the Court otherwise.

- I know; and, of course, no one is better acquainted with that fact than is the honorable member who interjects. But the remarks from honorable members opposite might mislead people into the idea that the mere fact of becoming a unionist necessarily involves a certain amount of benefit to the individual, whereas there is nothing of the kind attaching. The unanimity of honorable members opposite is to be attributed simply to the fact that preference is the first condition they desire to see imposed in all awards - a condition that has the support and imprimatur of the organizations they represent.
- They have not the pluck to put it in their platform.

- They have not the courage to go against the decision of those organizations. To illustrate my point, I should like to read a leading article iu the Sydney Worker of the 18th May, 1911, headed "Lest We Forget." This is a long editorial harangue to members of the Parliamentary Labour party, telling them exactly what they have to do, and what will happen if they do not do it. The following are extracts from that article -

quote.para: That which essentially distinguishes the Labour . Government is that it enacts the planks of the Labour platform, and regulates its administration by Labour principles.
But speaking by and large, it is unhappily only too true that there is a tendency in Labour Ministers to forget why they are where they are.

In the nature of the case, therefore, Labour Ministers are class representatives. They cannot represent every class in the community. As soon as they do so, as soon as they even attempt to do so, they are unfaithful to the principles and ideals by virtue of which they nave been raised from the obscure mass to the highest positions in the land.
We say this in no carping spirit. It is simply something which has to be said, and stressed with a warning inflection, for the sake of the future of our great movement.
Labour Ministers are not where they are because of their own compelling merit. . . . They are where they are as representatives of the working class, and of no other class.
If he is true to his trust, a Labour Minister cannot represent the employing class. He cannot represent the land-owning class.
He is where he is to represent the workers.

speech.para: This explains one reason why we have such unanimity opposite on this question. The Labour Conference has told the Parliamentary Labour party that they must support preference to unionists, and I should like to read one more quotation to rivet the fact. In the Argus of 5th April, the chairman of the Political Labour Conference in Melbourne is reported as having said -

quote.para: Labour members of Parliament have to confine their duties to putting the policy of the Conference before the people, elaborating it and voting for it.

speech.para: This means simply that honorable members opposite, if they wish to save their political skins, cannot, under any condition, do anything but oppose an alteration df the character now proposed. As to the Bill itself, it has my heartiest support, inasmuch as it declines to grant preference to any particular section of the community, whether they are individual unionists or otherwise. A Government has no more right to ask an applicant for employment whether he is a unionist or a non-unionist than it has to inquire whether he is a Jew or a Gentile Any man who contends that preference should be granted, unless on the simple lines of efficiency and merit, upholds a " principle that is of no earthly good.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member believe in judicial preference!
- I would believe in it if there were some reliable authority to certify to the competency of the individuals seeking preference.
- That is the good old cry of the employer.

- Not at all. The Labour party ask that preference shall be given on the statement of somebody who knows nothing of the applicants ; and I submit that no Government should accept such a position. I hail with considerable satisfaction the introduction of this measure, and I hope that it will be placed on the statute-book. You may remember, Mr. Speaker, that when I seconded the adoption of the Address-in-Reply I ventured to express the hope that the question of preference should not be a matter of regulation, but a matter of law, so that we should not have one Government refusing to concede it and the succeeding Government granting ii by regulation. The Bill goes in the direction I desired, and I therefore heartily support it and hope it will be carried.

.- I am pleased that the honorable member for Hume has been so candid as to tell us that we on this side are here to carry out our platform. That is a fact we all admit; and it is because we are faithful to our platform that we object to this Bill.
- Is preference in the Labour platform?

- When the Labour Government came into power, they, in conformity with their principles, gave an order that there should be preference to unionists, and the people who elected that Government did so with that policy in view. Honorable members opposite are quite consistent in introducing a Bill to nullify what the late Government did by regulation, because Liberal candidates declared that they were prepared, if they were returned to power, to abolish preference. I give them as much credit for consistency as I claim myself. I take it that the Bill means that all temporary employes of the Government shall in the future, under law, receive no preference. I would ask the Attorney-General t whether this Bill means that no preference shall be given to unionists who are employed temporarily by the Federal Government ?
- Yes, under an award or otherwise.

- In that case, the Ministry have brought in a Bill to do away with a thing which was established by the late Government by regulation, and which can be repealed by regulation. The Attorney-General has given us an assurance that the Government have already repealed the instructions issued by the late Government to give preference to unionists.
- The Bill will do more than that.

- I understand what is at the bottom of the Bill. If the Labour Government did wrong by giving preference to people temporarily employed in their service, the present Government have nullified it by wiping out that regulation. I now ask Ministers in what respect this Bill is going to affect temporary employes ?
- Under the law at present they can go before the Arbitration

speech.para: Court, and get an award against the Government for preference; but they will, not be able to do it under this Bill. '

talk.start.para: - That is the point, and I am glad the honorable member has ad,mitted it. Let us see the position at which we shall arrive. To-day we have! a statute that gives the public servants! the right to go to the Arbitration Court, and in that Act the Judge, if he thinks1 fit, can give a preference to the claimants. I wish to know what mandate the Government claim they have to repudiate the laws of the country and take this preference from these men ?

- Yes. It is unjust for the Government to come down with any mandate and flout the unionists who have gone to the trouble and expense of getting awards. When this Bill is passed they may flout the awards of the State Courts, and I do not think that is a fair position to take up. In fact, I do not think the Government can intend to take such ' a course. We must remember that the number of employes in our Departments is daily increasing; yet the Government are sheltering themselves behind this small Bill of six lines, which says that no preference shall be given. Why should the Government be able to shelter behind this Bill, while the private employer is compelled to give preference? The Government should be put on the footing of other employers of labour. In fact, the Government should be a model employer. The question is asked why the Labour party claim preference to unionists? The honorable member for Hume said that every time a union goes to an Arbitration Court one of its claims is for preference to unionists. There is a good reason for so doing. It is not that we desire any advantage over non-unionists, but that we may protect ourselves. When employers are cited to the Court, and compelled to give evidence and show their books, and when they see their employes go into the Court and give evidence against them, the mere fact that they- are put to expense and trouble in connexion with the matter raises in them a dislike towards those who have occasioned them tins trouble and loss, and, unless there is preference given to these employes, they are sacked. At least, that is our experience. It is almost impossible to get men to go into Court and give evidence against employers unless they are protected by the Court and given preference of employment. The honorable member for Hume talks of our using moral suasion, sometimes in the shape of a "brick."

speech.para: Have the other side never used moral suasion? Has it not been the case that, unless men got out of unions, they have been compelled to leave their employment ? There has been such a thing as putting into force the brutal weapon of poverty. It is the families - the women and children of the unionists - who have to suffer by the gentle method of starvation that employers have often used. As a Labour party- we do not wish to injure any part of the community. The history of the trade union movement shows that its effect has been to elevate the community and bring about its greater prosperity. Honorable members opposite say " We do not object to industrial unionism, but we object to political unionism." What is political unionism, and what is industrial unionism ? A union that was only industrial would never have advocated the bringing about of shorter hours of labour, because the Early Closing Act was brought about by legislation, and any union that seeks to bring about legislation must take political action, and so become a political union. In the early days, the unions advocated the introduction of the Factories and Shops Act, and that very fact would bring them under the heading of political unions. We, as an industrial organization, put all our strength and energy into the old-age pension scheme. We spent our money, formed deputations, and did everything we could to bring it about in the interests of the whole of the people; but the very fact that we did this would bring us under this Bill, because we took political action. Because we had so much human principle as to advocate a beneficial measure,, of that kind, the Attorney-General and the Government generally would say, " You shall not have the right to ask for preference in Government employment." Honorable members will see that this is a direct blow at the principles of unionism. There can be no union to-day unless it is political. Every act we perform has a political significance, and therefore we cannot exist as an industrial union without taking political action. Then, the Government say, you must not use your funds for political action. We have the right to say what we shall do with our own funds. It is our money, we earn it, and we are under no obligation to the employers to consult them is to how we shall spend it. It is a piece of presumption on the part of the Attorney -General and the Government to say that we cannot use our funds 'for political purposes. If a farmers' and settlers' association in the country took political action, going to the Government for some concession, the Government would not be justified in turning them down because they were a political body. The farmers, and settlers take an interest in politics, hold conferences,- and decide to run candidates, but no State Government would be justified in refusing to give them concessions on the railways, or to deal with them in any way, because they discuss politics. Similarly, when the squatters hold conferences to obtain a railway or to get a stock route altered, no objection is taken to political action on their part, and the same principle should apply to the working classes if they decide on political action.

talk.start.para: - The Government would not be justified in refusing those men if they were not an association.

- The same thing can be said of the members of the labour leagues. Why should they be penalized because they join an association? The Government have no mandate from, the people of this country for their present action. They say they are against unions because they use their funds for political purposes, but if it had not been for the workers having political objects this Parliament would never have seen Labour men. That is the whole trouble. The Attorney- General last night went to a good deal of trouble to traverse the history of the guilds to the present day, and admitted that the main object of the guilds was to make the workers perfect in the production of particular articles, but there were no large factories then, every man working in his own home, with his own family. In my young days, a bootmaker used to make the boots on his knee. He was the manufacturer, and took time over his work, and put all his capital into ' his business. To-day, we find all the work done in factories, which are full of machinery of the latest type, and a man handles a hundred pairs of boots for every pair that he handled thirty years ago. Everything has completely changed. The productive power of men has been increased, and we find them to-day associated in great bodies. They discuss their own wants and disabilities, and decide on a course of action. No Parliament should prevent those people from studying their own interests. Working amongst machinery is not good for young women to whom we look to be the mothers of our future generations. Our factory system is tending to the increase of nervous disorders and insanity, and it is wrong to deny factory workers the right to take political action to benefit themselves by securing better conditions of labour. Although this Bill may be passed, it has no substance in it,, because the unions today which have preference can get it without the aid of a Bill, or the aid of an Arbitration Court of a Wages Board award. This Bill does not affect the unions which have obtained preference, and which have been cited as acting tyrannically. They will still have their preference, and will still be able to enforce it. The only effect of the introduction of the Bill is that the Government will be able to say that they have carried out their pledges to the country to abolish preference in Government employment. All the civil servants are appointed by the Public Service Board, so that this Bill will not touch them. It will touch only the casual labourer who is employed from day to day and week to week, and who is in unions, many of which already have preference. We cannot take that preference from them.

If that be so, I say that the public never gave the Government a mandate -to repudiate the awards of that Court, and the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General ought to see if they cannot frame an amendment to ' prevent interference with the existing rights of public servants. speech.para: I should like honorable members to know the kind of unionists whom our friends opposite represent. Let me quote the following . from last night's Herald to show what Lord Milner has to say of them -
Scrambling for Capital.

An interesting address on " The Scrambles for Capital," was given by Lord Milner, as President of the Birmingham and Midland Institute, at Birmingham, on October 8. In a sense there was, he said, always a scramble for capital in every community; ten. years ago, when the. South African War was still recent, Consols stood at about 90. To-day they were 74 ; in other words, ten years ago the British Government could borrow at about £2 16s. per cent., while to-day it would have to pay £3 8s. A similar fate had overtaken the stocks of almost every Government in the world, which had been in the enjoyment of first-rate credit. Capital was no longer prepared to serve on the terms which it was formerly willing to accept. It had, so to speak, struck for higher wages.

It will be seen that the workmen are not the only people who strike for higher wages, but that capital is striking too, according to the authority of a capitalist. The only object of honorable members on this side in desiring that preference shall be given to unionists is to secure industrial peace. The reason why we entered the House as unionists was to get industrial peace, and the only way in which it can be obtained is by encouraging and making every effort to get the men in the various trades into the unions. If this measure passes, do honorable members on the other side think that they are going to do away with unionism ? It was distinctly stated by the carpenters on the Commonwealth building that they would not work with non-unionists. Had the non-unionists persisted in working, there would have been a sympathetic strike of the carpenters throughout Australia. The unionists will not work. with the non-unionists at the present time, and the trades people of Australia are so well organized that the Bill will not effect the object desired by the Government. . It is only fair to say that I learned a couple of days ago that that report was not written by him, and under these circumstances it is . only just that the remarks which I made should be withdrawn.
